metadata.case_name: Haji Gulamnabi Haji Safibhai v. Vora Abbasbhai

facts.text: Plaintiff is owner of premises in Baroda; defendant occupies as tenant on monthly rental of Rs. 70.
Notice dated December 1, 1956 served December 3, 1956, demanding possession for failure to pay rent since October 1, 1955.
Defendant's letter dated December 7, 1956: paid rent till April 1, 1956; entitled to credit Rs. 200 for electric installation with plaintiff's consent; rent excessive.
January 5, 1957: Defendant moves Civil Judge under s.11(1) for fixing standard rent and s.11(3) for interim rent.
January 7, 1957: Defendant informs plaintiff of application, requests appearance, willing to pay as ordered.
January 8, 1957: Defendant deposits Rs. 500 in court to credit of plaintiff.
January 27, 1957: Plaintiff institutes suit for ejectment on ground of non-payment of rent.
February 14, 1957: Defendant applies for order specifying interim rent rate; court orders deposit arrears at Rs. 51 per month within 15 days.
Defendant deposits Rs. 200 on March 2, 1957 and other sums; by February 11, 1958 aggregates Rs. 1,479 including Rs. 500.
March 28, 1958: Civil Judge dismisses ejectment; standard rent Rs. 50/month; paid till April 1, 1956; credit Rs. 150 for electric installation; deposits cover; ready and willing u/s.12(1).
District Court appeal: standard rent Rs. 70; no payment since Oct 1, 1955; no credit Rs. 150; but complied s.12(3)(b); ready and willing; confirms no ejectment, modifies standard rent.
Gujarat High Court in Revision Application No. 425 of 1960 dated August 14, 1962: reverses District Court; no ready and willing; no compliance s.12(3)(b); orders possession within 4 months.

legal_issues.text: Whether defendant complied with s.12(3)(b) of the Act by depositing interim rent, proving readiness and willingness to pay standard rent.
Whether High Court had jurisdiction u/s.115 CPC to reverse District Court in revision.

petitioner_arguments.text: Defendant not ready and willing; did not deposit standard rent at rate determined by District Court; did not pay interim rent fully or costs; dispute re standard rent must be raised before notice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Rents Act s.12(3)(b); s.115 CPC

respondent_arguments.text: Paid till Apr 1956; credit for electric installation; rent excessive; deposited pursuant to court orders; ready and willing.

court_reasoning.text: s.12(1) protects tenant if pays or ready/willing to pay standard rent; applies post-determination of tenancy.
Standard rent defined u/s.5(10A); fixed u/s.11(1); interim u/s.11(3) not standard rent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interim rent â‰  standard rent for s.12(3)(b).

court_reasoning.text: Explanation to s.12: application u/s.11(3) post-notice + payment of interim = presumption of readiness/willingness.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Conclusive evidence but not equates to standard rent payment.

court_reasoning.text: Defendant's case under s.12(3)(b) due to dispute on standard rent; deposits short of standard rent fixed; did not continue payments till end; but District Court found otherwise ready/willing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: District Court erred technically but found readiness.

court_reasoning.text: High Court revision u/s.115 CPC only for jurisdictional error, not mere error of law/fact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: District Court had jurisdiction; error does not invoke s.115.

holdings.text: Tenant must pay/tender standard rent u/s.12(3)(b), not just interim; but compliance with s.11(3) presumes readiness via Explanation.
High Court erred in exercising revisional jurisdiction u/s.115 CPC as no jurisdictional defect in District Court.

precedents_cited.relevance: 'May' in s.12(3)(a) mandatory if conditions fulfilled.
s.115 CPC applies to jurisdiction alone, not errors of law/fact.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Wrong decision on merits not jurisdictional error.

precedents_cited.case_name: Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Laksha Chaudhury
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguishes jurisdictional errors from merits errors for s.115.

precedents_cited.case_name: Manindra Land and Building Corporation v. Bhutnath Bannerjee
precedents_cited.relevance: s.115 not for errors within jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines standard rent; fixes interim; protects tenant if ready/willing to pay standard rent; conditions for eviction.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Revisional jurisdiction limited to jurisdictional errors.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; District Court decree restored (no ejectment); deposits since District Court order to be paid to plaintiff at Rs.70/month.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of decree denying ejectment; adjustment of deposits at standard rent Rs.70.

key_quotes.text: "A landlord shall not be entitled to the recovery of possession of any premises so long as the tenant pays, or is ready and willing to pay, the amount of the standard rent and permitted increases" - s.12(1).
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Section 115 CPC "applies to jurisdiction alone, the irregular exercise or non-exercise of it, or illegal assumption of it."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The observation made by the High Court... that the tenant must deposit costs of the suit along with the arrears... is... erroneous."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Corrects High Court error on s.12(3)(b).
